abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Irrigation Improvement
            Project for Yemen are as follows: outcomes of the project
            were highly moderately satisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was substantial, bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: improvement of
            spate irrigation management needs not only hardware
            interventions (rehabilitation and modernization of
            infrastructure) but also institutional development and
            information management measures. The project's
            Participatory Irrigation Management (PIM) and Agriculture
            Demonstration Program (ADP) components have resulted in very
            tangible progress towards achieving sustainable and
            efficient spate irrigation management and increasing
            agricultural productivity and rural incomes. To further
            develop and greatly extend these successes, they should be
            enhanced and replicated in other promising wadis under the
            recently approved Water Sector Support Project (WSSP). For
            future comparable projects including the WSSP, International
            Development Association (IDA), other donors and Government
            of Yemen (GoY) should specifically assure the financial
            sustainability of, and the modalities needed for, adequate
            Operation and Maintenance (O&M) of provided works and
            procured equipment.

5084906.trustfund:
TF039424-YEMEN, REPUBLIC OF - IRRIGATION IMPROVEMENT,TF039969-YEMEN - SANA'A BASIN WATER
            MANAGEMENT PROJECT,TF029513-PHRD-WATER SECTOR INVESTMENT PROJ.,TF025669-PHRD-PARTICIPATORY IRRIGATION
            MGMT. PROJECT,TF036528-MENA REGION - IRRIGATION IMPROVEMENT
5084906.majtheme: Public sector governance,Environment and natural resource management,Rural development,Rule of law

abstracts.cdata!:
The Irrigation Improvement Project is
            the first phase of the country's Program, to ensure
            sustainable water resources management in seven main spate
            irrigation schemes in Yemen, and improve agriculture
            productivity, and small-holder income in these areas. The
            project components are: 1) To support the rehabilitation,
            improvement, and protection of spate irrigation
            infrastructure, namely Tuban and Zabid schemes,
            topographical surveys, with detailed design, and hydraulic
            models testing will be implemented, with supervision on
            improvements of irrigation systems at the canal level,
            including wadi levels. This include construction of flood
            protection, and road rehabilitation works. 2) To enhance
            irrigation, and environment management, a participatory
            irrigation management approach will be established, that is,
            through water users associations (WUA), and a scheme water
            users federation, with joint management mechanisms, should
            provide institutional support. Operation and maintenance
            equipment will be provided, to be leased by the WUAs, and,
            supported by groundwater, and hydraulic monitoring. 3) An
            intensive agriculture demonstration program will provide
            improved agricultural practices, through extension services
            in technology transfer. 4) Institutional strengthening, and
            capacity building will support the relevant institutions in
            the irrigation sector, including legal framework support.

repnme.cdata!:
Yemen - Irrigation Improvement Project :
            environmental action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
Although the Irrigation Improvement
            Project aims at alleviating the water diversion, and
            distribution on the agricultural area covered by the Tuban,
            and Zabid wadis, potential environmental impacts include
            degradation of irrigation land, due to water salinity, and
            chemical pollutants, water-logging, erosion and
            sedimentation, in addition to the mining groundwater problem
            from the wadi Zabid. Consequently, health hazards arise,
            resulting from poor quality of drinking water, and low
            levels of hygiene, and sanitation. This Environmental Action
            Plan recognizes the need for coordination with other
            projects in the area, but suggests the project should lead
            in soil, and water management issues, and offers mitigating
            measures for: 1) mining ground-water on irrigation, and
            water supply, emphasizing the need to transfer water
            management responsibilities to the new wadi institutions,
            and to train extension workers, and farmers on water
            management for irrigation. Systemic ground-water monitoring,
            and testing should be undertaken, to be revised further on;
            2) soil erosion, and sedimentation, to be assessed through a
            rigid soil survey, and, a watershed study, to review, and
            formulate watershed management strategies; 3) sand dune, and
            river bank protection, to be selectively supported through
            mechanical, and vegetative control. Sanitation, and potable
            water issues will be addressed through different Bank operations.
